choices.text: Posterior segment of right upper lobe
Inferior lingular of left upper lobe
Posterior segment of Right lower lobe

questions.text: A bed-ridden patient on liquid diet develops aspiration pneumonia resulting a lung abscess. Which of the following is bronchopulmonary segment is most likely affected
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Posterior segment of right upper lobe. Aspiration pneumonia typically occurs when food, liquid, or other foreign materials are inhaled into the lungs, leading to infection. The right lung is more commonly affected in aspiration pneumonia due to its anatomical structure. The right mainstem bronchus is more vertical, shorter, and wider compared to the left, making it easier for aspirated material to enter the right lung, particularly into the right upper lobe. The posterior segment of the right upper lobe is the most common site for aspiration pneumonia because aspirated material often tends to settle in the upper segments of the right lung due to gravity, especially in a bedridden patient who is at higher risk for aspiration while lying down. This segment is more likely to be affected by lung abscess formation due to the infection following aspiration. Incorrect Options: B. Inferior lingular of left upper lobe (incorrect): While aspiration can also affect the left lung, it is less common in the left upper lobe, particularly the lingular segment, when compared to the right lung. The left mainstem bronchus is more angled and longer than the right bronchus, making it less likely for aspirated material to enter the left lung. Additionally, the lingula is located in a relatively dependent region of the lung, but aspiration typically favors the right side due to gravity. Therefore, this option is incorrect. C. Apical of Left lower lobe (incorrect): The apical segment of the left lower lobe is anatomically located in a less dependent area, which makes it a less common site for aspiration pneumonia, particularly in a bedridden patient. The lower lobes are more often affected than the upper lobes when aspiration occurs while the patient is in a supine position, but the left lower lobe does not commonly see infection in the apical segment in cases of aspiration. This makes this option incorrect. D. Posterior segment of right lower lobe (incorrect): The posterior segment of the right lower lobe is also a common site for aspiration pneumonia, but it is not the most typical site for lung abscess formation in a bedridden patient. The right upper lobe is more commonly involved, especially in the posterior segment, due to the ease with which aspirated material enters this area. While the posterior segment of the right lower lobe may also be affected, it is less likely to develop a lung abscess compared to the right upper lobe in this scenario. Therefore, this option is incorrect.

questions.text: A 28 yr female had diarrhoea, confusion, high grade fever with bilateral pneumonitis. The diagnosis:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Legionella. Legionella pneumonia, caused by Legionella pneumophila, often presents with a combination of symptoms such as high-grade fever, confusion, diarrhea, and bilateral pneumonitis (inflammation of the lungs). This condition is known as Legionnaires' disease. The presence of gastrointestinal symptoms (diarrhea), along with confusion and bilateral lung involvement, is highly suggestive of Legionella infection, which often presents with atypical pneumonia. It can also cause multi-organ involvement, including hepatic dysfunction, and is commonly acquired through inhalation of contaminated water vapor, such as from air conditioning systems or hot tubs. Incorrect Options: (B) Neisseria meningitis: Neisseria meningitidis is the causative agent of bacterial meningitis, which typically presents with symptoms such as fever, headache, neck stiffness, and altered mental status (e.g., confusion). While it can lead to sepsis, it is not associated with diarrhea or bilateral pneumonitis as primary features, making it an unlikely cause in this case. (C) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Streptococcus pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), but it typically presents with fever, cough, and unilateral consolidation on chest X-ray, not with the combination of diarrhea, confusion, and bilateral lung involvement. While it can cause severe infections, it does not typically present with the broad range of symptoms described here. (D) Klebsiella pneumoniae: Klebsiella pneumoniae is often associated with severe, lobar pneumonia, typically in patients with underlying lung disease, alcohol use disorder, or immunocompromise. It is more likely to cause a localized, rather than bilateral, infection and does not commonly present with gastrointestinal symptoms like diarrhea. While it can cause severe pneumonia, the clinical picture in this case is more consistent with Legionella.

choices.text: Most patients have CD4 counts <200 cells per μL at the time of diagnosis of their first episode of P. jiroveci pneumonia.
Most patients with P. jiroveci pneumonia will have an elevated serum lactate dehydrogenaselevel.
Arterial blood gases in patients with P. jiroveci pneumonia frequently reveal respiratory alkalosisand a widened alveoloarterial oxygen tension difference.
A normal chest radiograph rules out the diagnosis

questions.text: Regarding Pneumocystis jirovecipneumonia in HIV-infected patients, which of the following statement is false?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) A normal chest radiograph rules out the diagnosis. In patients with Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP), especially those with HIV infection and low CD4 counts, the chest radiograph is often abnormal. It typically shows diffuse bilateral infiltrates, sometimes with a "ground-glass" appearance. However, a normal chest radiograph does not rule out PCP, as some patients may have normal X-rays early in the disease, or the radiograph may not show the typical features. Therefore, a normal chest radiograph should not exclude the diagnosis of PCP, especially if the clinical suspicion is high. Incorrect Options: (A) Most patients have CD4 counts <200 cells per µL at the time of diagnosis of their first episode of P. jiroveci pneumonia: This statement is true. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is more common in HIV-infected individuals with CD4 counts below 200 cells per µL. This low CD4 count indicates severe immunosuppression, which predisposes patients to opportunistic infections such as PCP. As a result, a majority of patients will have CD4 counts under 200 at the time of their first PCP episode. (B) Most patients with P. jiroveci pneumonia will have an elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase level: This is also correct. Elevated serum lactate dehydrogenase (LDH) levels are commonly seen in patients with PCP, as LDH is released from damaged cells, including lung cells affected by the infection. Elevated LDH can be used as an indirect marker of tissue damage and inflammation in PCP. (C) Arterial blood gases in patients with P. jiroveci pneumonia frequently reveal respiratory alkalosis and a widened alveoloarterial oxygen tension difference: This statement is accurate. In PCP, arterial blood gases often show respiratory alkalosis due to tachypnea (rapid breathing) and hypoxemia. Additionally, there is usually a widened alveoloarterial oxygen tension gradient, indicating impaired gas exchange in the lungs due to the infection.

questions.text: The most common causative organism for lobar pneumonia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Streptococcus pneumoniae. Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common causative organism of lobar pneumonia, particularly in otherwise healthy individuals. It typically causes a severe, localized infection that results in consolidation of one or more lobes of the lung, which is characteristic of lobar pneumonia. This bacterium is the leading cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP) and is known for its rapid onset and severity in patients with no underlying conditions, as well as in those with comorbidities. Incorrect Options: (A) Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), can cause pneumonia, but it is less commonly the cause of lobar pneumonia. It is more often associated with necrotizing pneumonia, abscesses, and complications, especially in hospitalized or immunocompromised individuals. While it can cause severe pneumonia, it is not as common as Streptococcus pneumoniae in causing lobar pneumonia. (B) Streptococcus pyogenes: Streptococcus pyogenes, the causative agent of group A streptococcal infections, can cause pneumonia, but it is more often associated with complications of upper respiratory tract infections, like pharyngitis, or with severe infections such as necrotizing fasciitis or toxic shock syndrome. It is a less common cause of lobar pneumonia compared to Streptococcus pneumoniae. (D) Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of pneumonia, particularly in individuals with underlying lung disease, such as COPD or in smokers. However, it is less frequently responsible for classic lobar pneumonia and is more often associated with bronchopneumonia or other forms of pneumonia with a more diffuse distribution. It does not commonly cause the localized, lobar pattern seen in typical pneumonia caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae.

choices.text: OP treatment with Clarithromycin 500mg BID for one week
Admit in ward and give Levofloxacin orally 750mg OD + Inj. Ceftriaxone 1G IV BID for one week
Admit in ICCU and give Inj. Ceftriaxone 2G IV OD + IV levofloxacin 750mg OD for one week
Piperacillin + tazobactam 4.5 G qid for one week

questions.text: A 30 year previously healthy male came with 2 days fever and cough with purulent sputum. Examination reveals an impaired note with bronchial breathing and crackles and increased vocal resonance. He is alert. BP=100/70. Respiratory rate =24/min. Blood urea=20 mg%. Which of the following is the best treatment for him?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) OP treatment with Clarithromycin 500mg BID for one week. This patient presents with symptoms and signs suggestive of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), including fever, cough with purulent sputum, impaired percussion note, bronchial breathing, crackles, and increased vocal resonance. His vitals are stable with a respiratory rate of 24/min, blood pressure of 100/70, and no altered mental status, indicating he has mild CAP that does not require hospital admission. The CURB-65 score for this patient is 0 (no confusion, urea 90 systolic or 60 diastolic, and age < 65 years), which supports outpatient management. Clarithromycin is a macrolide antibiotic effective against the typical and atypical pathogens responsible for CAP, such as Streptococcus pneumoniae, Haemophilus influenzae, Mycoplasma pneumoniae, and Chlamydia pneumoniae. It is a first-line agent in treating mild CAP in otherwise healthy patients with no comorbidities or risk factors for drug-resistant organisms. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: (B) Admit in ward and give Levofloxacin orally 750mg OD + Inj. Ceftriaxone 1G IV BID for one week: This approach is overly aggressive for this patient. Hospital admission and the combination of levofloxacin (a respiratory fluoroquinolone) and ceftriaxone are typically reserved for patients with moderate to severe CAP or those with comorbidities, hemodynamic instability, or high CURB-65 scores. This patient’s vitals are stable, and there is no indication of severe disease, making ward admission unnecessary. (C) Admit in ICCU and give Inj. Ceftriaxone 2G IV OD + IV Levofloxacin 750mg OD for one week: This regimen is designed for critically ill patients, such as those with sepsis, respiratory failure, or shock due to severe CAP. The patient’s alertness, normal blood pressure, and lack of organ dysfunction exclude the need for ICU care. Administering high-dose ceftriaxone and levofloxacin in such a setting is excessive for a mild case like this. (D) Piperacillin + Tazobactam 4.5 G QID for one week: Piperacillin-tazobactam is a broad-spectrum antibiotic combination typically reserved for hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP), healthcare-associated pneumonia (HCAP), or severe CAP in patients with risk factors for multidrug-resistant organisms. This patient does not have risk factors such as recent hospitalization, immunosuppression, or exposure to healthcare settings. Therefore, this regimen is inappropriate for outpatient treatment of mild CAP.

choices.text: Multinucleate gaint cells in the bronchiolar wall

questions.text: All of following features are seen in the viral pneumonia except :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Predominance of alveolar exudates. In viral pneumonia, the hallmark is inflammation of the interstitial tissues (interstitial pneumonia) rather than the alveoli. Viral infections primarily target the respiratory epithelium and the interstitium, leading to interstitial inflammation, which is characterized by mononuclear cell infiltrates and thickening of the alveolar walls. Alveolar exudates, predominantly seen in bacterial pneumonia, result from acute inflammatory responses involving neutrophils that fill the alveoli, which is not typical of viral pneumonia. Hence, predominance of alveolar exudates is not a feature of viral pneumonia. Why Other Options Are Correct: (A) Presence of interstitial inflammation: This is a classic feature of viral pneumonia. Viruses such as influenza, respiratory syncytial virus (RSV), and adenoviruses primarily infect the interstitial tissues, causing inflammation and edema. The alveoli themselves are generally spared from the significant accumulation of exudates seen in bacterial pneumonia. Interstitial thickening is a hallmark finding in viral pneumonia on imaging. (C) Bronchiolitis: Bronchiolitis is a common feature of viral pneumonia, especially in infections caused by RSV, influenza, and parainfluenza viruses. Viral infections cause inflammation and damage to the bronchioles, resulting in symptoms such as wheezing and dyspnea. This is particularly seen in children and young adults. (D) Multinucleate giant cells in the bronchiolar wall: Multinucleate giant cells are a histopathological feature seen in certain viral pneumonias, particularly those caused by paramyxoviruses like RSV and measles. The viral infection leads to the formation of syncytial cells (giant cells), which are a response to viral replication and fusion of infected epithelial cells.

questions.text: 50-year-old woman was admitted to the hospital with fever and cough. She has had no past medical problems and was well untilabout 3 days ago. Physical examination is remarkable for a temperature of 39_C and the presence of bronchial breath sounds on right side chest. Except for an elevated white count with a leftshifted differential, her blood tests are normal. Chest radiography reveals Right sided opacity.Which of the following organism can produce the below feature?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Klebsiella pneumoniae. Klebsiella pneumoniae is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia (CAP), particularly in middle-aged or elderly patients with risk factors such as alcoholism, diabetes, or chronic illness, though it can also occur in previously healthy individuals. Klebsiella pneumonia typically produces a lobar consolidation visible as an opacity on chest radiographs, as seen in this patient. It is also associated with the production of thick, mucoid, "currant jelly" sputum, due to the organism's polysaccharide capsule. This encapsulation contributes to its virulence and the necrotizing nature of the infection, which can lead to abscess formation and cavitation in the lungs. The patient's high fever, bronchial breath sounds, and radiological findings of right-sided opacity are consistent with lobar pneumonia caused by Klebsiella pneumoniae. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: (A) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas is a common cause of hospital-acquired pneumonia (HAP) or ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and is typically seen in patients with significant comorbidities such as cystic fibrosis, bronchiectasis, or immunosuppression. It often causes a more diffuse pattern on chest radiographs rather than a lobar opacity. Given this patient's previously healthy status and lack of exposure to healthcare settings, Pseudomonas is an unlikely cause. (B) Escherichia coli (E. coli): E. coli is an uncommon cause of community-acquired pneumonia. When it does occur, it is usually in the context of healthcare-associated infections or in severely immunocompromised patients. It often presents as bronchopneumonia rather than lobar pneumonia. This patient’s clinical and radiological features are not typical for E. coli as the causative organism. (D) Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus, including methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), is a significant cause of post-viral pneumonia or hospital-acquired pneumonia, especially in patients with recent influenza infections or those with immunosuppression. It often causes bronchopneumonia with patchy infiltrates or cavitations rather than lobar consolidation. The absence of a recent viral illness or risk factors in this patient makes Staphylococcus aureus an unlikely cause.

questions.text: A 50 year old male was diagnosed with Mycoplasma pneumonia. The choice of a suitableantibiotic includes all of the following EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Beta-lactams. Mycoplasma pneumoniae is an atypical pathogen causing community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). It lacks a cell wall, making it inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics (e.g., penicillins, cephalosporins, and carbapenems), which target bacterial cell wall synthesis. Since Mycoplasma does not possess a peptidoglycan layer, beta-lactams are ineffective against it, making them unsuitable for treatment. Instead, antibiotics that target protein synthesis or DNA replication are required. Why Other Options Are Correct: (B) Macrolides: Macrolides, such as azithromycin and clarithromycin, are highly effective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae. They inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S ribosomal subunit and are often the first-line treatment for Mycoplasma infections. Macrolides are particularly preferred in children and pregnant women due to their safety profile. (C) Fluoroquinolones: Fluoroquinolones, such as levofloxacin and moxifloxacin, are effective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae. They target bacterial DNA gyrase and topoisomerase IV, inhibiting DNA replication. Fluoroquinolones are commonly used in adults, particularly in cases of more severe infections or when macrolides cannot be used due to resistance or intolerance. (D) Tetracyclines: Tetracyclines, such as doxycycline, are effective against Mycoplasma pneumoniae by inhibiting protein synthesis through binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit. They are an alternative to macrolides, especially in adults. However, their use is limited in children under 8 years of age and pregnant women due to the risk of teeth discoloration and bone growth suppression.

questions.text: Drug that can be used in treatment in PCP pneumonia are all except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Fluoroquinolones. Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PCP) is a severe opportunistic infection seen in immunocompromised patients, particularly those with HIV/AIDS. The treatment of PCP focuses on drugs that specifically target the organism's metabolic pathways. Fluoroquinolones are not effective against Pneumocystis jirovecii, as this pathogen lacks the typical bacterial structures or enzymes (such as DNA gyrase or topoisomerase IV) that fluoroquinolones target. Hence, fluoroquinolones are not used in the treatment of PCP. Why Other Options Are Correct: (A) Cotrimoxazole: Cotrimoxazole (trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole) is the first-line treatment for PCP. It works by inhibiting folate synthesis in Pneumocystis jirovecii, effectively disrupting its ability to reproduce. It is also used for prophylaxis in high-risk patients, such as those with low CD4 counts (<200 cells/μL) in HIV/AIDS. (B) Pentamidine: Pentamidine is an alternative to cotrimoxazole, used for the treatment of moderate to severe PCP or in patients who cannot tolerate cotrimoxazole. It can be administered intravenously for treatment or via inhalation for prophylaxis. Pentamidine interferes with the pathogen's RNA and DNA synthesis. (C) Dapsone: Dapsone, often used in combination with trimethoprim, is another alternative to cotrimoxazole for the treatment of PCP. It is effective in mild to moderate cases and is also used for prophylaxis. Dapsone works by inhibiting folate synthesis, similar to cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: A 40-year-old alcoholic develops cough and fever. Chest x-ray shows an air-fluid level in the superior segment of the right lower lobe. The most likely etiologic agent is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Anaerobes. This patient’s presentation, including cough, fever, and the presence of an air-fluid level on chest X-ray in the superior segment of the right lower lobe, is consistent with a lung abscess. Lung abscesses are commonly associated with aspiration, particularly in individuals with impaired consciousness, such as alcoholics. Anaerobic bacteria from the oral cavity (e.g., Peptostreptococcus, Fusobacterium, Prevotella, and Bacteroides species) are the most likely etiologic agents because they are introduced into the lower airways during aspiration. Alcoholics are at higher risk for aspiration due to depressed cough reflexes, altered mental status, and poor oral hygiene. Anaerobic infections typically lead to necrotizing pneumonia or abscess formation, often presenting with putrid sputum and constitutional symptoms like fever. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: (A) Streptococcus pneumoniae: Although Streptococcus pneumoniae is the most common cause of community-acquired pneumonia, it typically presents as lobar pneumonia without abscess or air-fluid levels on imaging. Lung abscesses caused by Streptococcus pneumoniae are rare and would usually occur in immunocompromised individuals or as a secondary complication. (B) Haemophilus influenzae: Haemophilus influenzae is associated with bronchopneumonia or exacerbations of chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). While it can cause pneumonia, it rarely leads to abscess formation or air-fluid levels. This organism is unlikely in an otherwise healthy adult without underlying pulmonary disease. (C) Legionella: Legionella pneumophila causes Legionnaires’ disease, a form of atypical pneumonia characterized by systemic symptoms such as confusion, diarrhea, and hyponatremia. It typically presents with patchy or lobar infiltrates on chest X-ray, not air-fluid levels or abscesses. Aspiration or anaerobic infection is a more likely cause in this clinical scenario.

questions.text: Most commonorganism agent for early onset noscomial pneumonia
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Streptococcus pneumoniae. Early-onset nosocomial pneumonia refers to pneumonia that occurs within the first 4–5 days of hospital admission. In these cases, the causative organisms are often similar to those seen in community-acquired pneumonia (CAP). Streptococcus pneumoniae, a common cause of CAP, is the most likely etiologic agent in early-onset nosocomial pneumonia. This is because patients hospitalized for a short period are less likely to be colonized by multidrug-resistant (MDR) organisms, and the infection often arises from community-acquired pathogens already present in the respiratory tract. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: (A) Staphylococcus aureus: Staphylococcus aureus, particularly methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), is a significant cause of late-onset nosocomial pneumonia (developing after 5 days of hospitalization). It is typically associated with patients who have been exposed to invasive devices (e.g., ventilators) or those who are immunocompromised. While it can occasionally cause early-onset pneumonia, it is not the most common organism in this scenario. (C) Klebsiella: Klebsiella pneumoniae is a Gram-negative bacterium more commonly associated with late-onset nosocomial pneumonia or in patients with risk factors such as diabetes, alcoholism, or prolonged hospital stays. It is also a common pathogen in ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP). Early-onset pneumonia is less frequently caused by Klebsiella. (D) Pseudomonas aeruginosa: Pseudomonas aeruginosa is a key pathogen in late-onset nosocomial pneumonia, particularly in immunocompromised patients or those with structural lung diseases (e.g., bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis). It is a highly resistant organism that colonizes hospitalized patients over time. It is not typically implicated in early-onset nosocomial pneumonia.

questions.text: In patients with severe structural lung disease, such as bronchiectasis the infective agent most likely to cause pneumonia is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) P. aeruginosa. In patients with severe structural lung disease like bronchiectasis, Pseudomonas aeruginosa is the most likely causative pathogen for pneumonia. This is because P. aeruginosa is a common pathogen in individuals with chronic lung conditions due to its ability to colonize the airways and form biofilms, making it difficult to eradicate. It is more prevalent in patients with bronchiectasis, cystic fibrosis, or chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), where the structural damage to the airways increases the risk of recurrent infections. The pathogen can cause severe, chronic infections and is known for its antibiotic resistance mechanisms, which make it challenging to treat. Why Other Options Are Incorrect: (A) H. Influenza: Haemophilus influenzae is a common cause of respiratory tract infections in individuals with bronchiectasis and can contribute to pneumonia in such patients. However, while it is a frequent pathogen in bronchiectasis, it is less likely to cause the severe infections seen in the setting of advanced bronchiectasis compared to Pseudomonas aeruginosa, which is known to be more virulent in these patients. Thus, H. Influenza is not the most likely cause of severe pneumonia in this group. (B) Pneumococcus: Streptococcus pneumoniae (pneumococcus) is a common cause of community-acquired pneumonia and can cause pneumonia in patients with bronchiectasis. However, P. aeruginosa tends to be more prevalent and problematic in patients with severe structural lung diseases like bronchiectasis. Pneumococcus is more associated with acute infections and is generally seen in patients without significant chronic lung disease or in those with milder forms of lung disease. (C) Legionella: Legionella pneumophila is a less common cause of pneumonia, typically associated with contaminated water sources, such as air-conditioning units and water systems. While Legionella infections can cause severe pneumonia, it is not the most common pathogen in patients with bronchiectasis, and it is more often associated with outbreaks or specific environmental exposures rather than being the primary pathogen in chronic lung conditions like bronchiectasis.

questions.text: The following are main diagnostic criteria for Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Distal bronchiectasis. In Allergic Bronchopulmonary Aspergillosis (ABPA), the key diagnostic criteria include clinical, radiological, and laboratory findings that reflect a hypersensitivity response to the fungus Aspergillus. Distal bronchiectasis is not a primary diagnostic feature of ABPA. Instead, proximal bronchiectasis, particularly in the central airways, is more commonly observed. Although bronchiectasis can occur in ABPA, it is not limited to the distal regions of the lungs and is not considered a defining diagnostic feature of the condition. Why the other options are correct: A. Pulmonary infiltrate: Pulmonary infiltrates, often in the form of eosinophilic pneumonia or fleeting opacities, are common in ABPA. These infiltrates are part of the inflammatory response to Aspergillus colonization and hypersensitivity, making them a central diagnostic feature. C. Bronchial asthma: Asthma is a key component of ABPA. Most patients with ABPA have pre-existing asthma, and exacerbations of asthma are often seen during fungal sensitization. The presence of asthma along with other findings strongly suggests ABPA. D. Peripheral eosinophilia: Peripheral eosinophilia is one of the hallmark findings in ABPA. This elevated eosinophil count in the blood is reflective of the immune response to the Aspergillus antigen and is commonly seen in patients with ABPA, aiding in its diagnosis.

questions.text: Hot tub lung is related to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Mycobacterium avium complex. Hot tub lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis that occurs due to inhalation of contaminated water droplets from hot tubs, spas, or whirlpools. The bacterium Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC) is the most common causative organism. This bacterium is found in warm, moist environments like hot tubs, and when inhaled, it can lead to inflammation of the lung tissue, manifesting as hot tub lung. It typically presents with symptoms such as cough, shortness of breath, fever, and fatigue, and is associated with granulomatous inflammation. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Isocyanates: Isocyanates are chemicals that can cause occupational asthma and hypersensitivity pneumonitis, but they are not linked to hot tub lung. Isocyanates are commonly found in industries like painting, foaming, and manufacturing, not in hot tubs. C. Molds in air conditioners: Molds can cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis when inhaled, but they are typically associated with environments where mold growth is prominent, such as in air conditioning systems or poorly ventilated spaces. However, molds in air conditioners are not the primary cause of hot tub lung. D. Legionella: Legionella is a type of bacteria that causes Legionnaires' disease, a form of pneumonia typically linked to contaminated water sources like cooling towers or air conditioning systems. While Legionella can cause respiratory infections, it is not the causative organism of hot tub lung.

questions.text: Causative agent of farmer‘s lung is:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Thermophilus actinomycetes. Farmer’s lung is a type of hypersensitivity pneumonitis caused by the inhalation of organic dust, which often contains actinomycetes, a group of bacteria. Specifically, Thermophilus actinomycetes is a key causative agent of this condition. These bacteria are commonly found in moldy hay, straw, or silage—common materials that farmers or agricultural workers may be exposed to. The inhalation of these dust particles can trigger an immune response in the lungs, leading to inflammation, coughing, shortness of breath, and other symptoms of farmer's lung. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Aspergillus: Aspergillus is a genus of molds that can cause various types of lung disease, such as aspergillosis. While Aspergillus species can contribute to allergic bronchopulmonary aspergillosis (ABPA) or fungal infections, it is not the primary causative agent of farmer's lung, which is mainly associated with actinomycetes. C. Penicillium glabrum: Penicillium glabrum is another species of mold, but it is not typically associated with farmer’s lung. While Penicillium species can contribute to respiratory issues, they are not the main cause of the hypersensitivity pneumonitis seen in agricultural workers. Thermophilus actinomycetes are far more commonly implicated in this condition. D. Rhizopus: Rhizopus is a mold genus that can cause infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals, leading to conditions like mucormycosis. However, it is not the causative agent of farmer’s lung. The condition is most commonly linked to exposure to thermophilic actinomycetes found in organic dust on farms, not Rhizopus.

questions.text: Endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis presents in a patient with prior
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All. Endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis is a condition where Aspergillus species, typically Aspergillus fumigatus, colonize the bronchial tree, forming a saprophytic growth. This condition is more common in individuals with a history of lung diseases that cause chronic lung damage or alterations in lung architecture. The underlying diseases like pulmonary tuberculosis (TB), sarcoidosis, and histoplasmosis can predispose patients to this condition by causing fibrosis, cavities, or altered immune responses in the lungs, creating an environment where Aspergillus can grow. Why the other options are correct: A. Pulmonary TB: Pulmonary tuberculosis (TB) can lead to lung cavities, which provide an ideal environment for the growth of Aspergillus species. Patients with chronic pulmonary TB often have structural lung damage, such as cavities or fibrosis, which can facilitate the development of endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis. B. Sarcoidosis: Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory condition that can lead to lung fibrosis and scarring, creating a favorable environment for the growth of Aspergillus. It is also associated with granulomas, which can sometimes house fungal organisms, including Aspergillus. Therefore, sarcoidosis is another predisposing factor for endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis. C. Histoplasmosis: Histoplasmosis, caused by the fungus Histoplasma capsulatum, can result in lung lesions, granulomas, and fibrosis. These lung abnormalities can predispose individuals to develop endobronchial saprophytic pulmonary aspergillosis. The chronic damage caused by histoplasmosis provides an opportunity for Aspergillus colonization in the airways.

choices.text: acute respiratory failure thatoften requires mechanical ventilation

questions.text: Regarding Acute eosinophilic pneumonia true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Poor clinical response to corticosteroids. Acute eosinophilic pneumonia (AEP) is a rare, rapidly progressive disorder characterized by an eosinophilic infiltrate in the lungs. It typically presents with acute respiratory failure and can progress rapidly, requiring mechanical ventilation in some cases. The key to its treatment is corticosteroids, which usually result in a significant clinical improvement. AEP responds well to corticosteroid therapy, and this is why the statement that AEP has a "poor clinical response to corticosteroids" is incorrect. Why the other options are correct: A. Acute respiratory failure that often requires mechanical ventilation: Acute eosinophilic pneumonia often presents with severe respiratory distress, which can progress to acute respiratory failure. This is due to diffuse pulmonary infiltrates and hypoxemia. In severe cases, mechanical ventilation may be required to support the patient while they are being treated. B. Diffuse pulmonary infiltrates: Diffuse pulmonary infiltrates are a hallmark of acute eosinophilic pneumonia. These infiltrates are typically visible on chest radiography and CT scans, and they correspond to the accumulation of eosinophils and other inflammatory cells in the lungs. The infiltrates contribute to the acute respiratory symptoms seen in this condition. C. Bronchoalveolar lavage eosinophilia >25%: In acute eosinophilic pneumonia, bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is often performed to help diagnose the condition. The eosinophil count in BAL fluid is typically greater than 25%, which helps confirm the diagnosis. This is one of the diagnostic criteria for AEP, as the presence of eosinophils in the airways and alveoli is central to the pathophysiology of the disease.

choices.text: Most patients are female nonsmokers with a mean age of 45

Lung biopsy is often required to establish adiagnosis

questions.text: Regarding Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia true except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Lung biopsy is often required to establish a diagnosis. Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia (CEP) is a condition characterized by chronic eosinophilic infiltration in the lungs. Unlike other pulmonary conditions, a lung biopsy is rarely required to establish the diagnosis of CEP. The diagnosis is usually made based on clinical symptoms, radiographic findings, and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) results. In many cases, the diagnosis can be confirmed with non-invasive tests, such as imaging studies and BAL fluid analysis, which show a high percentage of eosinophils. Therefore, a lung biopsy is typically not needed to diagnose chronic eosinophilic pneumonia, making option D the false statement. Why the other options are correct: A. Most patients are female nonsmokers with a mean age of 45: Chronic eosinophilic pneumonia typically affects middle-aged females, and the majority of patients are nonsmokers. The mean age of diagnosis is around 45 years, which is consistent with the characteristic patient profile for this condition. B. Negative photographic pulmonary edema appearance on chest x-ray and chest CT is pathognomonic: Chest X-ray and CT findings in chronic eosinophilic pneumonia often show infiltrates that may have a "photographic pulmonary edema" appearance, which refers to the pattern of consolidation or "ground-glass opacities" in a peripheral and basal distribution. This appearance is indeed a pathognomonic feature for chronic eosinophilic pneumonia. C. Mean BAL eosinophil counts of ~60%: Bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) is a key diagnostic tool in chronic eosinophilic pneumonia. A mean eosinophil count of approximately 60% in BAL fluid is commonly seen in patients with CEP. The high proportion of eosinophils in the lavage fluid supports the diagnosis of chronic eosinophilic pneumonia, reflecting the inflammatory response in the lungs.

choices.text: Exposure to a known offending antigen

questions.text: What is the strongest predictor of the diagnosis of HP?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Exposure to a known offending antigen. Hypersensitivity pneumonitis (HP) is an inflammatory response in the lungs caused by inhalation of organic dust, fungi, or other environmental antigens. The strongest predictor of HP is exposure to a known offending antigen, which can be a specific mold, bird droppings, or other particles that trigger the immune response. Identifying a direct link between the patient's symptoms and exposure to a specific antigen is essential for confirming the diagnosis. Therefore, the strongest predictor is knowing the patient has had contact with an antigen known to cause hypersensitivity pneumonitis. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Symptoms 4-8 hours after exposure: While symptoms often occur 4-8 hours after exposure to the offending antigen in acute hypersensitivity pneumonitis, this is not the strongest predictor of the diagnosis. Symptoms may vary and may also occur hours or days after exposure, and this timing alone is insufficient to confirm the diagnosis. Knowing the specific antigen causing the reaction is much more definitive. B. Recurrent episodes of symptoms: Recurrent episodes of symptoms are characteristic of chronic hypersensitivity pneumonitis, where repeated exposures lead to ongoing inflammation. However, while recurrent symptoms may be a clue to the diagnosis, they do not provide a stronger predictive value than identifying a specific offending antigen, which is a more direct link to the condition. C. Positive precipitins: Positive precipitins indicate the presence of specific antibodies to antigens related to hypersensitivity pneumonitis. However, having positive precipitins alone is not enough to confirm the diagnosis, as they can be present in other conditions or in individuals with no symptoms. Therefore, the presence of precipitating antibodies is important, but exposure to the known offending antigen is a stronger predictor.

questions.text: A 20 years old women presents with a dry cough and dyspnoea. A Chest X-ray has beenperformed and demonstrates bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy with bilateral well defined 3mmparenchymal nodules. The diagnosis is most likely to be?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Stage 2 sarcoidosis. Stage 2 sarcoidosis is characterized by bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy (enlarged lymph nodes in the chest) along with bilateral pulmonary parenchymal nodules on imaging. The patient's symptoms of dry cough and dyspnea combined with the chest X-ray findings of hilar lymphadenopathy and well-defined 3mm nodules are consistent with this stage of the disease. Sarcoidosis is a granulomatous disorder that often affects young adults, and the chest X-ray findings are crucial in staging the disease. Stage 2 typically includes lymphadenopathy and lung parenchymal involvement. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Stage 0 sarcoidosis: Stage 0 sarcoidosis refers to a condition where there are no chest X-ray abnormalities present, meaning no visible lung or lymph node involvement. The presence of bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy and pulmonary nodules on the chest X-ray eliminates this as a possibility for this patient. B. Stage 1 sarcoidosis: Stage 1 sarcoidosis is characterized by isolated bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy, without any pulmonary parenchymal involvement (no nodules). While this patient does have hilar lymphadenopathy, she also has pulmonary nodules, which would place her diagnosis at Stage 2 rather than Stage 1. D. Stage 3 sarcoidosis: Stage 3 sarcoidosis is marked by pulmonary parenchymal fibrosis and significant lung involvement, which often presents with reticulonodular infiltrates or fibrotic changes seen on imaging. This patient's chest X-ray does not show the typical findings of fibrosis or advanced pulmonary changes that are characteristic of Stage 3. Additionally, the patient's symptoms (dry cough and dyspnea) are more consistent with an earlier stage of the disease rather than the fibrosis seen in Stage 3.

questions.text: A Female presents with history of progressive breathlessness. Histology shows heterogenouspatchy fibrosis with several fibroblastic foci. The most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP). Usual interstitial pneumonia (UIP) is characterized by a heterogeneous pattern of patchy fibrosis with fibroblastic foci on histology. These fibroblastic foci are indicative of areas of active fibrosis. UIP is the histopathologic pattern seen in idiopathic pulmonary fibrosis (IPF), which often presents with progressive breathlessness. The histologic features of UIP include patchy fibrosis, honeycombing, and areas of normal lung tissue interspersed with fibrotic tissue, which is consistent with the description provided in this case. The fibroblastic foci (areas where fibroblasts proliferate) suggest ongoing fibrosis, a hallmark of UIP. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Cryptogenic Organizing Pneumonia (COP): Cryptogenic organizing pneumonia (COP), previously known as bronchiolitis obliterans organizing pneumonia (BOOP), is characterized by fibrosis in the small airways and alveolar spaces, leading to the formation of polypoid plugs of granulation tissue. This condition is usually more homogeneous compared to the patchy and heterogeneous fibrosis seen in UIP. COP typically presents with a cough and dyspnea rather than the progressive breathlessness seen in UIP, and it lacks the characteristic fibroblastic foci found in UIP. B. Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP): Non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) presents with uniform fibrosis and inflammation without the marked architectural distortion seen in UIP. On histology, NSIP shows mild to moderate fibrosis without the fibroblastic foci or honeycombing seen in UIP. The fibrosis in NSIP is typically more homogeneous than the patchy and heterogeneous fibrosis found in UIP, making it less likely in this case. The progressive breathlessness and patchy fibrosis with fibroblastic foci point more toward UIP. D. Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP): Desquamative interstitial pneumonia (DIP) is a form of interstitial lung disease typically associated with smoking and is characterized by alveolar macrophage accumulation in the airspaces. On histology, DIP shows marked alveolar inflammation and macrophage infiltration with minimal fibrosis, unlike the patchy fibrosis seen in UIP. It is also not associated with the prominent fibroblastic foci that characterize UIP. Additionally, the pattern of fibrosis described in the case is not typical for DIP.

questions.text: All are correct regarding sarcoidosis except
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Cavity commonly seen. Sarcoidosis is an inflammatory disease that often presents with noncaseating granulomas and is most commonly found in the lungs and lymph nodes. One of its hallmark features is bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy on chest imaging, and it does not typically lead to the formation of cavities in the lungs. Cavitary lesions are more characteristic of tuberculosis or other infectious diseases but are not commonly seen in sarcoidosis. Therefore, statement A is incorrect. Why the other options are correct: B. Spontaneous remission is usual: Sarcoidosis often shows spontaneous remission, especially in mild cases. Many patients experience an initial worsening of symptoms, followed by gradual improvement without treatment, especially in early-stage sarcoidosis. In some cases, it resolves completely without requiring significant intervention. C. Tuberculin test is negative: Sarcoidosis is characterized by negative tuberculin skin tests (also known as the TST or PPD test). Unlike tuberculosis, sarcoidosis is not caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis, and patients with sarcoidosis typically do not react to the tuberculin test, which is used to test for exposure to tuberculosis. D. Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy: Bilateral hilar lymphadenopathy is a classic finding in sarcoidosis. It is commonly observed in chest X-rays and is a key radiographic feature of the disease. The presence of enlarged lymph nodes in the chest is often a distinguishing factor of sarcoidosis and is present in up to 90% of patients with the disease.

questions.text: A 75/M is referred for dyspnoea on exertion and chronic cough that have worsened progressively over the past12 months. PFT shows restriction with DLCO of 38% predicted. The chest radiograph shows bilateral patchyinfltrates, mostly at the lung bases. On HRCT, bilateral reticular opacities and clustered basal honeycombing arefound. Open-lung biopsy reveals randomly distributed fibrotic foci surrounded by normal lung parenchyma. What isthe most appropriate therapy for this patient?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Pirfenidone. This patient's presentation is consistent with Idiopathic Pulmonary Fibrosis (IPF), which is a type of interstitial lung disease (ILD). The clinical symptoms of dyspnea on exertion and chronic cough, along with the radiographic findings of bilateral patchy infiltrates, reticular opacities, and honeycombing on HRCT, strongly suggest IPF. The fibrotic foci surrounded by normal lung parenchyma seen on biopsy is a typical finding in IPF. The most appropriate therapy for IPF includes anti-fibrotic drugs, and pirfenidone is one of the FDA-approved agents for treating IPF. Pirfenidone is known to slow disease progression by inhibiting fibrosis and inflammation in the lungs. It has been shown in clinical studies to reduce the decline in lung function and improve survival in patients with IPF. Why the other options are incorrect: B. Bosentan: Bosentan is an endothelin receptor antagonist used primarily for the treatment of pulmonary arterial hypertension (PAH). Although PAH can occur in association with interstitial lung disease, it is not the first-line therapy for IPF. Bosentan would not be effective in treating the underlying fibrosis or improving the respiratory symptoms in IPF. C. Acetylcysteine: Acetylcysteine is an antioxidant and mucolytic agent. It has been studied in ILD, particularly in chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and bronchiectasis, but it does not have proven benefit in IPF. There is no strong evidence supporting its use in the treatment of IPF to improve outcomes or reduce fibrosis. D. Prednisolone/azathioprine: Prednisolone and azathioprine are immunosuppressive agents that may be used in certain inflammatory interstitial lung diseases, such as non-specific interstitial pneumonia (NSIP) or acute exacerbations of IPF. However, they are not effective for IPF and may even worsen outcomes in some patients with IPF. Immunosuppressive therapy is generally not recommended as first-line treatment for IPF due to potential harm and lack of benefit.

questions.text: A 25 Yr old male with fever, cough and expectoration, SOB 2 months duration. CECT chest showing B/L upper lobe fibrotic lesions, mediastinal necrotic Lymphnodes with peripheral rim enhancement. Diagnosis can be :
questions.solution: Correct Answer (B) Tuberculosis (TB). The patient's clinical presentation and CECT chest findings are most consistent with tuberculosis: Clinical presentation: The patient is presenting with fever, cough, expectoration, and shortness of breath for 2 months. These are classic symptoms of pulmonary tuberculosis (TB). TB can cause chronic cough, fever, weight loss, and night sweats, which are all consistent with this presentation. CECT chest findings: The bilateral upper lobe fibrotic lesions and mediastinal necrotic lymph nodes with peripheral rim enhancement are strongly suggestive of tuberculosis. The upper lobe involvement is typical of TB as the bacteria preferentially affect the upper lobes due to the higher oxygen content. Mediastinal lymphadenopathy with necrosis and rim enhancement is often seen in active TB and is a characteristic feature in adult pulmonary tuberculosis. Chronicity and systemic symptoms: The patient's symptoms have been persistent for 2 months, which is common for TB, which typically presents with a prolonged course. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Sarcoidosis: While sarcoidosis can present with mediastinal lymphadenopathy and upper lobe lesions, it typically does not cause necrotic lymph nodes with peripheral rim enhancement, which is more characteristic of infections such as TB. Sarcoidosis usually presents with non-caseating granulomas and often has a more insidious onset without the systemic infection symptoms like fever and expectoration seen in TB. C. Lymphoma: Lymphoma can cause mediastinal lymphadenopathy, but it does not typically present with upper lobe fibrotic lesions or necrotic lymph nodes with the typical peripheral rim enhancement seen in TB. Lymphoma usually presents with painless swelling of lymph nodes and does not cause the same chronic cough, expectoration, and fever as seen in TB. D. Silicosis: Silicosis is a form of pneumoconiosis caused by inhalation of silica dust and usually presents with lung fibrosis, particularly in workers exposed to silica dust. However, it does not typically cause necrotic lymph nodes or the upper lobe involvement with the characteristic imaging features seen in this patient. Silicosis typically has a more insidious onset and is not associated with systemic infection symptoms such as fever and cough.

choices.text: Antigens from all BCG strains and nontuberculous mycobacteria are present in the assay
Specificity of the test is superior to Tuberculin skin test in BCG vaccinated patients
Sensitivity is comparable to Tuberculin skin test
Sensitivity is reduced in HIV infection with low CD4 count

questions.text: The following are true regarding Interferon Gamma release assays in tuberculosis EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Antigens from all BCG strains and nontuberculous mycobacteria are present in the assay. Interferon Gamma Release Assays (IGRAs), such as the QuantiFERON test, do not use antigens from all BCG strains and nontuberculous mycobacteria. Instead, they use specific tuberculosis-specific antigens (like ESAT-6 and CFP-10) that are present in Mycobacterium tuberculosis but are not found in BCG or most nontuberculous mycobacteria. This makes IGRAs more specific for Mycobacterium tuberculosis infection compared to the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST), which may cross-react with antigens from BCG or nontuberculous mycobacteria. Why the other options are correct: B. Specificity of the test is superior to Tuberculin skin test in BCG vaccinated patients: This statement is true. IGRAs are more specific than the Tuberculin Skin Test (TST) in BCG-vaccinated individuals. Since the TST may react to BCG-derived antigens, it may give a false-positive result in BCG-vaccinated individuals. On the other hand, IGRAs are based on antigens that are not present in the BCG vaccine, thereby reducing the likelihood of false positives in those who have received BCG vaccination. C. Sensitivity is comparable to Tuberculin skin test: This statement is true. IGRAs and the TST have comparable sensitivities when it comes to detecting latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI). However, neither test is perfect, and sensitivity can be reduced in individuals with weakened immune systems, such as those with HIV or very young children. D. Sensitivity is reduced in HIV infection with low CD4 count: This statement is true. IGRAs may show reduced sensitivity in individuals with HIV, particularly when the CD4 count is very low. This is because the ability to mount a strong immune response (including gamma interferon production) may be compromised in those with immunocompromised conditions such as advanced HIV/AIDS. Therefore, IGRAs may not be as effective in detecting latent tuberculosis infection in these patients.

choices.text: No further action is necessary at this time
Repeat the skin test if CD4 cells fall below 200/uLd
Prophylactic therapy with isoniazid for 6 months

questions.text: A 45-year-old HIV-positive male (CD4 cells 250 per uL), is referred to you because of atuberculin skin test with 7-mm induration. He has no specifc complaints, has not had contact with tuberculosis patients in the past. Chest radiography is normal. Which one of the following is the most appropriate next step?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Prophylactic therapy with isoniazid for 6 months. This patient, who is HIV-positive with a CD4 count of 250/uL, has a 7-mm induration on the tuberculin skin test (TST), which is considered a positive result in an HIV-infected individual. The threshold for a positive TST in someone with HIV is 5 mm, meaning that any induration of 5 mm or more is suggestive of latent tuberculosis infection (LTBI), even if the patient is asymptomatic and has no known contact with tuberculosis (TB) patients. Since his chest radiograph is normal and there is no indication of active TB, the most appropriate next step is to initiate prophylactic therapy with isoniazid for 6 months to reduce the risk of developing active TB in the future. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Perform an interferon-γ release assay (IGRA): While IGRAs (such as the QuantiFERON-TB test) can also be used to diagnose latent TB infection, performing this test is not the most appropriate next step in this case. The TST result is already positive, and given the patient's HIV status and 7-mm induration, prophylactic therapy with isoniazid is the next appropriate step, regardless of the IGRA result. B. No further action is necessary at this time: This is incorrect. A 7-mm TST induration in an HIV-positive patient, even without specific complaints or known contact with TB patients, suggests latent tuberculosis infection. This is a high-risk group for progressing to active TB, so prophylactic therapy with isoniazid is necessary to prevent this progression. C. Repeat the skin test if CD4 cells fall below 200/uL: This is incorrect. The patient's TST result is already positive with a 7-mm induration, which warrants intervention. Repeating the skin test is not necessary, and delaying treatment until the CD4 count falls below 200/uL would not be appropriate. Immediate prophylactic therapy with isoniazid is the recommended course of action to prevent the development of active TB in the future.

choices.text: It causes mild intermittent fever and anemia
It is commonly seen in children

questions.text: Regarding cryptic miliary tuberculosis all are correct EXCEPT
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) It is commonly seen in children. Cryptic miliary tuberculosis typically affects adults more frequently than children. It is characterized by a chronic, subtle progression, with patients presenting with nonspecific symptoms such as mild fever, anemia, and weight loss. Although children can develop miliary tuberculosis, it is not commonly seen in children. In fact, miliary tuberculosis is more often seen in immunocompromised adults, particularly those with HIV or malnutrition. Why the other options are correct: A. It has a chronic course: This is correct. Cryptic miliary tuberculosis usually has a chronic course, with a gradual onset of symptoms. Patients may present with nonspecific symptoms that can be easily overlooked, making the diagnosis more difficult. The disease progresses slowly and often presents with mild fever, weight loss, and general malaise. B. It causes mild intermittent fever and anemia: This is correct. One of the hallmark features of cryptic miliary tuberculosis is the presence of mild intermittent fever and anemia. These symptoms are part of the generalized systemic response to infection, and anemia results from chronic disease and bone marrow suppression. Mild fever is often intermittent and can be mistaken for other less serious conditions. C. Meningeal involvement precedes death: This is correct. Meningeal involvement in cryptic miliary tuberculosis can occur in severe cases, and it is often the leading cause of death in these patients. Meningitis due to miliary tuberculosis can be particularly challenging to diagnose, and it may lead to neurological deterioration and death if not recognized and treated promptly.

choices.text: flu like syndrome is usually seen with rifampicin being taken on daily basis
hyperuricemia is recognised side effect of pyrazinamide
red green colour impairement is an early sign of ethambutol induced optic neuritis

questions.text: All of the following are true about the therapy of tuberculosis except:
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) flu-like syndrome is usually seen with rifampicin being taken on a daily basis. Rifampicin is an essential drug in the treatment of tuberculosis (TB), but flu-like syndrome is not a common side effect of rifampicin, particularly when taken on a daily basis. While it may cause side effects such as hepatotoxicity or rash, flu-like symptoms are more likely to occur with intermittent dosing schedules (e.g., thrice-weekly dosing) or in the presence of drug-drug interactions. Rifampicin can also cause red-orange discoloration of bodily fluids but is not typically associated with flu-like symptoms when taken daily. Why the other options are correct: B. Ethambutol accumulates in renal failure: This is correct. Ethambutol is primarily excreted by the kidneys, and in renal failure, its levels may accumulate, increasing the risk of toxicity. Ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is a potential adverse effect, and its risk is heightened if the drug accumulates due to impaired renal function. C. Hyperuricemia is a recognized side effect of pyrazinamide: This is correct. Pyrazinamide is a first-line anti-TB drug that can cause hyperuricemia as a side effect. This occurs because pyrazinamide inhibits uric acid excretion, potentially leading to gout or renal problems in susceptible patients. Patients on pyrazinamide should be monitored for elevated uric acid levels. D. Red-green color impairment is an early sign of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis: This is correct. One of the early signs of ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is red-green color impairment, which is often the first visual symptom. This condition can progress to vision loss if not detected and managed early. Ethambutol-induced optic neuritis is dose-dependent, and monitoring of visual acuity is recommended during treatment.

choices.text: Pyrazinamide and any one of the fluoroquinolones
Ethambutol and any one of the fluoroquinolones
Any one of second line aminoglycosides and one of the Fluoroquinolones
Vancomycin and one of the fluoroquinolones

questions.text: Extensive drug resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) is defined as multidrug resistant TB (MDR- TB) strain that becomes resistant to
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Any one of second-line aminoglycosides and one of the fluoroquinolones. Extensive drug-resistant tuberculosis (XDR-TB) is a form of multidrug-resistant tuberculosis (MDR-TB) that is defined as TB resistant to: Isoniazid and rifampicin (as in MDR-TB), and Any one of the second-line aminoglycosides (such as amikacin, kanamycin, or capreomycin) and any one of the fluoroquinolones (such as levofloxacin or moxifloxacin). This extended resistance makes XDR-TB much more difficult to treat, requiring more complex and expensive treatment regimens. Why the other options are incorrect: A. Pyrazinamide and any one of the fluoroquinolones: This is incorrect because XDR-TB does not specifically require resistance to pyrazinamide. Resistance to pyrazinamide can occur in MDR-TB, but it is not a defining characteristic of XDR-TB. The defining feature of XDR-TB involves resistance to second-line aminoglycosides and fluoroquinolones, not just pyrazinamide. B. Ethambutol and any one of the fluoroquinolones: This is incorrect because ethambutol resistance is not a defining characteristic of XDR-TB. While ethambutol resistance can be seen in MDR-TB, it is not part of the criteria for XDR-TB. The key factors are resistance to fluoroquinolones and second-line aminoglycosides. D. Vancomycin and one of the fluoroquinolones: This is incorrect because vancomycin is not typically used in the treatment of tuberculosis. Vancomycin is an antibiotic used to treat gram-positive infections, not tuberculosis. XDR-TB is specifically defined by resistance to second-line TB drugs, not vancomycin.

questions.text: What does N in N-95 mask stands for ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Not resistant to oil. The "N" in N-95 refers to the mask's resistance to oil. Specifically, N-95 masks are designed to filter out at least 95% of airborne particles, including non-oil-based particles, but they are not resistant to oil-based particles. This means that if there is exposure to oil-based aerosols, the mask's efficiency is reduced. The "N" designation indicates that the mask is not rated for oil protection, whereas other masks like P95 are designed to provide protection against oil-based particles. Incorrect Responses: A. Not resistant to bacteria: This is incorrect because N-95 masks are designed to filter out particles, including bacteria, to a significant extent. The mask’s effectiveness is based on the filtration of particles with a size of 0.3 microns or larger, which includes many bacterial pathogens. While the N-95 mask is effective against various bacteria, its "N" designation does not refer to bacterial resistance. B. Not resistant to virus: This is incorrect because the N-95 mask is effective in filtering out viral particles, especially those transmitted by respiratory droplets, like SARS-CoV-2. The "N" does not indicate any lack of resistance to viruses; rather, it indicates resistance to oil particles, which is a different matter entirely. D. Not resistant to mycobacteria: While the N-95 mask can filter out many airborne pathogens, including mycobacteria (like Mycobacterium tuberculosis), the "N" designation does not specifically refer to resistance to mycobacteria. The N-95 mask is effective in a variety of environments but its primary indication is the ability to filter out particulate matter, including those from viruses and bacteria, rather than being a specific barrier to mycobacteria.

choices.text: Patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise and headache
Patients (adults) with presence of clinical features of dypnea and or hypoxia, fever, cough, SPO2 24/minute
Children with dyspnea, fever, cough, SpO2 60/min, 2-11 months > 50/min and 1-5years > 40/minute)

questions.text: What is moderate COVID-19 pneumonia ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) Both B and C. Moderate COVID-19 pneumonia is characterized by the presence of dyspnea (difficulty breathing) and/or hypoxia (low oxygen levels), and it can be observed in both adults and children. In adults, the clinical features include fever, cough, dyspnea, SpO2 24/min. In children, it includes dyspnea, fever, cough, SpO2 60/min, 2-11 months >50/min, and 1-5 years >40/min). Explanation of Incorrect Options: A. Patients with uncomplicated upper respiratory tract infection, may have mild symptoms such as fever, cough, sore throat, nasal congestion, malaise, and headache: This describes mild COVID-19 or upper respiratory tract infection (URI). These patients typically do not have significant respiratory distress or hypoxia and are not classified as having pneumonia. This option is not consistent with moderate COVID-19 pneumonia, which involves more severe respiratory symptoms. B. Patients (adults) with presence of clinical features of dyspnea and/or hypoxia, fever, cough, SpO2 24/minute: This option accurately describes moderate COVID-19 pneumonia in adults. Patients may have significant respiratory symptoms, including dyspnea, hypoxia, and increased respiratory rate, which fits the criteria for moderate pneumonia. C. Children with dyspnea, fever, cough, SpO2 60/min, 2-11 months >50/min, and 1-5 years >40/minute): This option correctly identifies the clinical features of moderate COVID-19 pneumonia in children. Tachypnea (rapid breathing) based on age group and hypoxia (SpO2 < 94%) are key indicators.

questions.text: SARS CoV 2 is spread by
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Both. Explanation: SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, can be spread through multiple routes: Respiratory droplets and aerosols – The primary method of transmission. When an infected person coughs, sneezes, talks, or breathes, they release respiratory droplets containing the virus that can be inhaled by others. In enclosed spaces with poor ventilation, aerosol transmission, involving smaller droplets suspended in the air, can also occur. Fecal-oral route – Though less common, there is evidence suggesting that the virus can be found in feces and can be transmitted through contaminated surfaces or improper sanitation. While this is not the main route, it has been documented in certain cases, particularly in patients with gastrointestinal symptoms or poor hygiene practices. Therefore, SARS-CoV-2 can be spread by both respiratory droplets and aerosols, as well as potentially by the fecal-oral route. Explanation of Incorrect Options: Option A: Feco-oral route – Incorrect. The fecal-oral route is not the primary mode of transmission for SARS-CoV-2. While the virus may be found in stool, transmission is primarily through respiratory droplets and aerosols, not via the digestive system. Option B: Air droplets – Incorrect. This option is partially correct but not complete. SARS-CoV-2 is primarily spread through respiratory droplets and aerosols, but it is not limited to just air droplets. The possibility of fecal-oral transmission, although less significant, also exists. Option D: None – Incorrect. SARS-CoV-2 is indeed spread through respiratory droplets and aerosols, as well as the fecal-oral route in some cases, so the answer is not None.

questions.text: True statement for SARS CoV-2 is ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (D) All of the above. Explanation: SARS-CoV-2, the virus that causes COVID-19, belongs to a specific taxonomic classification: Option A: It’s order is Nidovirales – Correct. SARS-CoV-2 is a member of the order Nidovirales, which includes viruses that have a characteristic large RNA genome. This order consists of viruses that can cause infections in humans and animals, such as coronaviruses and arteriviruses. Option B: It belongs to family Coronaviridae – Correct. SARS-CoV-2 belongs to the family Coronaviridae. This family includes a wide range of viruses that infect mammals and birds, with coronaviruses being known for their distinctive crown-like appearance due to the spike proteins on their surface. Other coronaviruses in this family include SARS-CoV and MERS-CoV. Option C: It belongs to subfamily Orthocoronavirinae – Correct. Within the family Coronaviridae, SARS-CoV-2 is classified under the subfamily Orthocoronavirinae, which encompasses all coronaviruses that primarily affect humans and other animals. This subfamily contains several genera, including Alphacoronavirus, Betacoronavirus (which includes SARS-CoV-2), Gammacoronavirus, and Deltacoronavirus.

questions.text: Which anti HIV drugs were used to treat COVID-19
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Protease inhibitors. Explanation: Protease inhibitors (PIs), particularly lopinavir/ritonavir, were initially used to treat COVID-19 patients. These drugs are part of the antiretroviral therapy for HIV and were repurposed during the early stages of the COVID-19 pandemic based on the similarity between the SARS-CoV-2 virus and HIV in terms of viral replication processes. Lopinavir and ritonavir inhibit the viral protease enzyme, which is essential for the virus to mature and replicate. Despite early interest, clinical trials later showed limited effectiveness for COVID-19 treatment, but protease inhibitors were one of the first HIV drugs considered. Incorrect options: Option A: NRTI (Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors) – Incorrect. While NRTIs are used in HIV treatment to inhibit the reverse transcriptase enzyme, they were not a primary treatment strategy for COVID-19. NRTIs, such as zidovudine and lamivudine, do not have direct efficacy against the SARS-CoV-2 virus. Option B: NNRTI (Non-Nucleoside Reverse Transcriptase Inhibitors) – Incorrect. NNRTIs, such as efavirenz and nevirapine, also target reverse transcriptase in HIV but were not commonly used to treat COVID-19. These drugs are not known to have significant antiviral activity against SARS-CoV-2. Option D: Integrase inhibitors – Incorrect. Integrase inhibitors like dolutegravir and raltegravir are used in HIV therapy to block the integrase enzyme, preventing the viral DNA from integrating into the host genome. While these drugs are highly effective in HIV, they were not prioritized for COVID-19 treatment, as they do not directly inhibit SARS-CoV-2 replication.

questions.text: Which anti HIV drugs were used to treat COVID-19
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Ritonavir/lopinavir. Explanation: Ritonavir/lopinavir was one of the main antiretroviral combinations considered for the treatment of COVID-19 during the early stages of the pandemic. Both ritonavir and lopinavir are protease inhibitors that work by inhibiting the replication of the virus. Ritonavir, in particular, is often used as a "booster" for other protease inhibitors like lopinavir. The combination was investigated for its potential to reduce viral replication in SARS-CoV-2, the virus responsible for COVID-19, although subsequent studies did not support its effectiveness as a treatment for COVID-19. Incorrect Responses: A. Zidovudine: Zidovudine is a nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NRTI) used primarily in the treatment of HIV. While NRTIs have antiviral properties, they were not specifically used in the treatment of COVID-19. B. Nevirapine: Nevirapine is a non-nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitor (NNRTI) used in HIV treatment. Like zidovudine, nevirapine was not a focus for COVID-19 therapy. D. Dolutegravir: Dolutegravir is an integrase inhibitor used to treat HIV. While it is a critical drug for HIV management, it was not widely investigated or used for treating COVID-19.

questions.text: Which anti helminthic is under trials /to treat COVID-19 ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Ivermectin. Explanation: Ivermectin is an anti-helminthic medication that has been investigated for potential use in treating COVID-19. Ivermectin has antiviral properties in vitro and was considered as a possible treatment for SARS-CoV-2 during the early phases of the pandemic. It is thought to inhibit the replication of the virus by interfering with the viral protein transport within host cells. However, while early laboratory studies showed promising results, larger clinical trials have yielded mixed outcomes, and its use for COVID-19 is not widely recommended outside of research settings. Incorrect Responses: B. Pyrantel: Pyrantel is an anti-helminthic used primarily for treating intestinal parasitic infections, such as pinworms. There is no significant evidence to suggest that pyrantel is effective against COVID-19. C. Albendazole: Albendazole is another anti-helminthic drug used to treat a variety of parasitic infections. While it has broad-spectrum activity against helminths, there is no evidence to support its use in the treatment of COVID-19. D. Mebendazole: Mebendazole is used to treat parasitic worm infections, similar to albendazole, and has no proven efficacy in treating COVID-19.

questions.text: Minimum distance to be maintained from a person who is sneezing or coughing is
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) 6 feet. Explanation: According to health guidelines, it is recommended to maintain a minimum distance of 6 feet (approximately 2 meters) from a person who is sneezing or coughing. This distance is based on the understanding that respiratory droplets, which may carry viruses like SARS-CoV-2, can travel up to 6 feet before falling to the ground. By maintaining this distance, you reduce the risk of inhaling these droplets, thus minimizing the chance of transmission. Incorrect Responses: A. 1 foot: This is too short a distance and does not provide sufficient protection. Respiratory droplets can travel much farther than 1 foot, especially when a person is sneezing or coughing. B. 2 feet: While this is a better distance than 1 foot, it is still not sufficient to reduce the risk of virus transmission effectively. The 6 feet distance is scientifically supported as being more protective. D. 4 feet: While a distance of 4 feet may offer some protection, it is still not the recommended distance. The 6 feet distance is widely accepted as a safer standard.

questions.text: What is mRNA-173 ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Under trial vaccine. Explanation: mRNA-173 refers to a vaccine that is currently under trial. It is an experimental mRNA-based vaccine developed to combat COVID-19. The mRNA vaccines work by instructing cells to produce a protein similar to the spike protein of the SARS-CoV-2 virus, thereby stimulating an immune response that helps protect the body from infection. This vaccine is part of a newer approach to vaccine development and is being evaluated in clinical trials to determine its safety and efficacy. Incorrect Responses: A. A type of RNA: mRNA (messenger RNA) is a type of RNA, but mRNA-173 specifically refers to a vaccine candidate, not a generic type of RNA. So, this is not the correct answer. B. Type of coronavirus: mRNA-173 is not a type of coronavirus. It is a vaccine being developed to prevent infection by the SARS-CoV-2 virus, which causes COVID-19, but it is not related to the virus itself. D. Drug for treating coronavirus: mRNA-173 is not a drug for treating COVID-19. It is a preventive vaccine. Treatments for COVID-19 would involve antivirals or other supportive medications, whereas mRNA-173 is designed to prevent infection by stimulating an immune response.

choices.text: Injecting plasma of sick person in its own body
Injecting plasma of healthy person in another healthy person
Injecting plasma of recovered person in sick person
Injecting plasma of healthy person in sick person

questions.text: Convalescent plasma therapy means ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (C) Injecting plasma of recovered person in sick person. Explanation: Convalescent plasma therapy involves the use of blood plasma from individuals who have recovered from a particular illness, such as COVID-19, to treat patients who are currently sick with the same illness. The plasma contains antibodies that the recovered person’s immune system developed during their infection, which can help the sick person fight the infection. This therapy is based on the idea that the passive transfer of antibodies may provide immediate immunity and support to the infected patient. Incorrect Responses: A. Injecting plasma of sick person in its own body: This option is incorrect because the therapy does not involve reinjecting plasma from a sick person into their own body. Convalescent plasma therapy is about transferring plasma from a recovered patient to a sick patient, not self-administering plasma from the same individual. B. Injecting plasma of healthy person in another healthy person: This is incorrect because convalescent plasma therapy requires plasma from a recovered person (not necessarily a "healthy" person) who has antibodies to the disease, and it is used to treat a sick person, not another healthy person. D. Injecting plasma of healthy person in sick person: This option is incorrect because plasma from a healthy person would not have the necessary antibodies needed to treat the infection. Only plasma from a recovered person who has been exposed to the virus contains the antibodies needed for therapy.

questions.text: Concept of plasma therapy is based on ?
questions.solution: Correct Answer (A) Passive immunity. Explanation: The concept of plasma therapy is based on passive immunity, which involves transferring antibodies from an immune individual to a susceptible individual. In convalescent plasma therapy, the plasma from a person who has recovered from an illness (such as COVID-19) contains antibodies that the immune system of the recovered person has produced to fight the disease. When this plasma is transferred to a sick patient, these pre-formed antibodies provide immediate immune protection, helping the patient’s body fight off the infection. This type of immunity does not require the recipient’s body to produce antibodies on its own but instead receives them from an external source. Incorrect Responses: B. Active immunity: Active immunity occurs when an individual’s own immune system is exposed to a pathogen (such as through vaccination or infection), and the body produces its own antibodies. In contrast, plasma therapy does not rely on the recipient producing their own antibodies but rather involves the direct transfer of antibodies, which is passive immunity. C. Cellular immunity: Cellular immunity involves immune cells like T-cells that help in the immune response against pathogens. Plasma therapy, however, primarily involves antibodies in the plasma, which are part of the humoral immune response, not the cellular immune response. D. Herd immunity: Herd immunity occurs when a significant portion of the population becomes immune to a disease, either through vaccination or previous infection, reducing its spread. Plasma therapy does not involve the concept of herd immunity, as it is focused on providing immunity to an individual rather than a population.

choices.text: Pore size of mask is 95 microns.
